subtitle: Competition, when it is in moderation and in a healthy way, actually is a force that
brings us to excellence.
Let's talk about a simple example in sports.
In sports you have competing teams or competing individuals.
You ask Novac Djokovic, who was the number one tennis player (I don't know where he is
now, but he was there), and they asked him how he improved his game over time.
They asked him, "What was the key?"
And he said,"The key was my opponents."
When Roger Federer and Nadal and some others kept beating him, it drove him crazy and he
was jealous of their success.
But that jealousy, instead of driving him to become negative and bitter and wanting
them to fail, made him a better player.
When you don't have competition like that you will never achieve excellence.
Most of us would say, "I'd rather not have the competition and not achieve excellence
than have to worry about competition."
I understand that.
It's human nature.
That's the lazy human being.
But the Talmud is telling us healthy competition is what drives you.
It's like you play against someone else -- you never know how strong you are until there
is resistance.
How will you ever develop anything you are doing if there is no one who is challenging
you?
